item.title: Why Reddit Isn‚Äôt the Best Place to Get Addiction Treatment Advice
item.dc:creator: Rob Lloyd
item.description: Reddit is not clinical. It‚Äôs not moderated by therapists, addiction medicine specialists, or safeguarding professionals. And most importantly, it doesn‚Äôt know you.
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôve spent nearly eight years working in the addiction treatment space – writing, creating, learning and helping clinics communicate better with the people they serve. While I‚Äôve never personally had a substance issue that needed treatment, I have ADHD, and I‚Äôve dealt with enough compulsive behaviours to understand how easy it is to fall into a cycle that feels impossible to break.

One thing I‚Äôve seen increasingly over the last few years, especially among younger people and neurodivergent communities, is a growing reliance on Reddit for addiction advice. I get it. Reddit feels real, unfiltered and raw. It‚Äôs where people speak the truth others are too scared to say out loud – but I‚Äôve also seen the harm it causes. Not because people are bad but because the platform is built to reward emotion over evidence and upvotes over nuance.

So if you’re scrolling r/addiction, r/stopdrinking, or similar subs looking for guidance, please keep reading. This isn‚Äôt a takedown of Reddit; it‚Äôs a conversation about where it fits and where it fails in the world of recovery.

Reddit Can Be a Lifeline, But It’s Not a Treatment Plan

Let me be clear: I‚Äôve read incredible threads on Reddit. Moments of compassion, honesty, and mutual support that would rival any therapy room. There‚Äôs power in peer communities, and sometimes hearing ‚Äúme too‚Äù from a stranger at 2am can feel life-saving (2am is when my brain is most active).

But here‚Äôs where it gets tricky.

Reddit is not clinical. It‚Äôs not moderated by therapists, addiction medicine specialists, or safeguarding professionals. And most importantly, it doesn‚Äôt know you. It doesn‚Äôt know your mental health history, your trauma background, your medication interactions, or how many units you‚Äôve been drinking per day. Reddit doesn‚Äôt know whether you‚Äôre in withdrawal or burnout. It can‚Äôt tell if your drinking is masking PTSD, or if your ‚Äújust one more night‚Äù will lead to seizures.

Yet advice is thrown around like truth, often from people with no qualifications, just a strong opinion and a few thousand karma points.

The Misinformation Loop: When the Reddit Echo Chambers Take Over

One of the most common patterns I see on Reddit is what I call the echo loop. It looks like this:

  1. Someone posts a vulnerable question: ‚ÄúShould I detox cold turkey?‚Äù

  2. A few commenters reply, ‚ÄúI did it and was fine.‚Äù

  3. Others add, ‚ÄúRehabs just want your money anyway.‚Äù

  4. The post gets upvoted. The risky advice gets reinforced.

And just like that, the really bad advice becomes the top answer.

This isn‚Äôt a Reddit-specific problem; it‚Äôs a platform design problem. On Reddit, the content that rises is content that feels right, not content that is right. That means emotional stories get more traction than evidence-based responses. Posts with nuance like ‚Äúit depends on your medical history, speak to a GP‚Äù – get buried.

In addiction, that‚Äôs dangerous.

Reddit Doesn‚Äôt Screen for Trauma, ADHD or Mental Health Risks

One of the most harmful myths I see is the idea that addiction is just about willpower. That you can ‚Äúsee it through‚Äù if you want it badly enough. But having worked with hundreds of people in recovery, I know this is dangerously simplistic.

Many people who struggle with alcohol or drug use have co-occurring conditions:

  • ADHD

  • Complex PTSD

  • Depression and anxiety

  • Autism spectrum traits

  • Grief, neglect, abuse, or childhood trauma

When Reddit users offer advice without understanding these layers, they unintentionally cause harm. Telling someone to “just quit” without acknowledging their nervous system dysregulation is like telling a drowning person to “just swim”.

Trauma needs context. ADHD needs a flexible structure. Autism needs sensitivity. Addiction needs care and understanding – not upvotes.

Real Lives, Real Consequences

In my line of work, I‚Äôve heard stories I‚Äôll never forget. But some of the “advice” I have personally witnessed on Reddit is terrifying

Like the teenager who posted on r/opiates asking how to taper using someone else‚Äôs leftover meds.

Or the woman who was told that 12 Step was ‚Äúa cult”.

Or perhaps the worst advice I have ever seen on Reddit: “You only need to worry about withdrawal symptoms if you’re drinking tons of spirits every day”.

These are not fringe cases. This is what happens when the loudest voice wins, and context is left out of the equation.

Not to mention that Reddit advice can be country-specific. Doctors in the US may charge “huge sums of money” for detox medication, but that isn’t the case here in the UK.

The Bias Against Professional Help

One thing that surprises many people is how much anti-treatment, anti-medical rhetoric exists on Reddit. This isn’t just specific to addiction or recovery, but I see it everywhere, from diet recommendations to herbal remedies.

  • ‚ÄúRehab is just a money-making scam‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúTherapists make money by keeping you stuck‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAA brainwashes you”.

Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong. Criticism of the addiction treatment industry, or any industry, is perfectly valid. I‚Äôve worked in this space long enough to know that recovery is a difficult journey for many people. There are bad actors, overpriced services, and outdated methods. But the solution isn‚Äôt throwing the whole system out. It‚Äôs improving it, expanding access, and increasing transparency.

Unfortunately, many Reddit threads skip that part. They move from personal frustration to broad generalisations. And for someone in a fragile state, scared, ashamed and confused – that can be enough to push them away from getting real help.

I Loved Reddit Until It Made Me Anxious

This part is personal. As someone with ADHD, Reddit felt like a perfect fit: fast, unpredictable, full of novelty. But that constant flood of opinions? The never-ending scroll of ‚Äúthis worked for me‚Äù vs ‚Äúyou‚Äôre doing it wrong‚Äù became overwhelming.

I started noticing how often I‚Äôd leave Reddit feeling more anxious than when I logged on. Instead of clarity, I had information fatigue. Instead of guidance, I had ten contradicting opinions and no idea which one to trust.

For someone seeking support with something as serious as addiction, that overwhelm can become paralysis. And paralysis, in recovery, is incredibly risky.

How to Spot Harmful Advice on Reddit

Not all Reddit advice is dangerous – but the lines get blurry when you’re desperate for clarity. In the early stages of change, you‚Äôre vulnerable, your nervous system is overloaded and your inner critic is screaming. And Reddit? Reddit is loud.

Here are some red flags I‚Äôve learned to spot both as someone with ADHD and as someone working in addiction recovery spaces:

1. Absolute Statements

Advice that starts with ‚ÄúYou should always‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚Äúnever trust‚Ä¶‚Äù lacks nuance. Recovery is deeply individual. What works for one person may harm another. Be wary of any advice that feels binary or overly confident.

Of course, context is important here. If the recommendation is “you should always speak to a medical professional before attempting a benzodiazepine detox”, that is really good advice. 

2. Anecdotes Masquerading as Evidence

Someone saying, ‚ÄúI quit after 10 years cold turkey, and I‚Äôm fine,‚Äù isn‚Äôt data. It‚Äôs a personal story. Powerful, yes – but not a blueprint. Especially when you’re dealing with medical risk, trauma, or co-occurring conditions.

3. Anti-Treatment Sentiment

Criticism of systems is healthy. But if someone dismisses all rehab, therapy, medication, or support groups based on one experience‚Äîor none‚Äîthat’s not guidance. That‚Äôs projection.

4. Dismissive or Shaming Comments

Recovery requires self-compassion. Any post or comment that shames you for struggling, mocks your attempts, or suggests you’re ‚Äúnot trying hard enough‚Äù is toxic, whether it has 2 upvotes or 2,000.

5. Algorithmic Echoes

Posts with thousands of upvotes might feel more trustworthy. But Reddit rewards what‚Äôs popular, not what‚Äôs safe. Don‚Äôt confuse karma with credibility.

Safer Alternatives to Reddit for Addiction Support

Let‚Äôs be honest: Google can feel overwhelming. And Reddit is familiar, accessible, even comforting. But there are better places to find help.

Here‚Äôs where I signpost people instead:

1. NHS and Local Free Services (UK)

  • NHS Alcohol Support

  • Change Grow Live

  • Turning Point

These are free, confidential, and connected to wider health support systems.

2. Residential Rehab

For people with high-risk alcohol or drug use, trauma history, or repeated relapses, residential rehab can be an important stepping stone in the recovery journey. I have been fortunate to work with some of the best in the UK and Abbington House is no exception.

3. Peer Support With Clinical Anchoring

  • AA and NA

  • SMART Recovery

Regardless of where you are in your journey, meetings should always be a key component of recovery. I recommend that you take a look at this study if you have any doubts.

4. Therapy

Trauma-aware therapy has helped me in many ways over the years. Look for someone experienced in:

  • Addiction and compulsive behaviours

  • ADHD or autism (if applicable)

  • Complex trauma (C-PTSD)

  • Emotional regulation and nervous system work.

What to Do If You‚Äôve Already Been Misled by Reddit Advice

If you’ve followed Reddit advice that made things worse, I want you to hear this loud and clear:

It‚Äôs not your fault.

Here‚Äôs how to reset:

1. Get a Real Person Involved

Whether it‚Äôs a GP, therapist, our team here at Abbington House, or loved ones – bring someone offline into your process. Algorithms don‚Äôt know your history.

2. Review What You Need

  • Do you need medical detox?

  • Do you need trauma support?

  • Do you need clarity, structure, or just a place to feel safe?

If you are unsure about some of these questions, our team here at Abbington can help you make an informed decision.

3. Give Yourself Grace

You don‚Äôt need to prove anything. Recovery isn‚Äôt a race, and it certainly isn‚Äôt a Reddit karma game. It‚Äôs a deeply human, deeply nonlinear process.

Why I Wrote This

I didn‚Äôt write this to bash Reddit. I‚Äôll never shame anyone for seeking help anywhere they feel safe enough to ask for it.

But as someone who has spent years working in this industry, I know that a one-size-fits-all approach to recovery doesn’t work. There are no absolutes or certainties.

Because the truth is:

  • Recovery is hard enough without misinformation

  • You deserve real support

  • Help should empower you, not confuse, shame, or mislead you

  • You‚Äôre allowed to be curious, cautious and critical all at the same time.
